statement.text: Below-knee amputation (BKA) is a major limb amputation at the transtibial level that preserves the knee joint, enabling prosthetic rehabilitation and ambulation in appropriately selected patients.
statement.formal: Level: 12-15 cm below tibial tuberosity; Healing rate: 80-90% with adequate perfusion; Prosthetic ambulation: 70-80% at 2 years; Mortality: 10-15% at 30 days (comorbid population)

explanation.intuition: When the foot cannot be saved, keeping the knee is the next best option. A preserved knee allows for a below-knee prosthesis which requires far less energy to walk with than an above-knee prosthesis.
explanation.key_insight: Preserving the knee joint dramatically improves prosthetic rehabilitation success - energy expenditure for walking is 40-60% higher with AKA than BKA.
explanation.technical_details: Below-knee amputation (transtibial amputation) is performed at the junction of the upper and middle thirds of the tibia, typically 12-15 cm below the tibial tuberosity. A long posterior myocutaneous flap provides durable soft tissue coverage. The tibia is beveled anteriorly to prevent skin breakdown. The fibula is cut 1-2 cm shorter than the tibia. Adequate perfusion assessment and patient selection are critical for healing success.
common_misconceptions: AKA heals better than BKA - FALSE, similar healing rates with proper selection
All CLTI patients should get AKA for reliability - FALSE, preserve the knee when possible
BKA patients rarely walk - FALSE, 70-80% achieve prosthetic ambulation
Short stump is not worth having - FALSE, even short BKA better than AKA

primary: Extensive foot gangrene extending to ankle
Overwhelming foot sepsis not responding to debridement

relative: Non-ambulatory patient (consider AKA for wound management)
No popliteal pulse with non-reconstructable inflow

clinical: Skin warmth and color at proposed flap level

level.minimum: Enough for prosthetic socket (5-7 cm below tibial tuberosity)
level.principle: Preserve as much length as perfusion allows

bone_transection.periosteum: Strip 1 cm proximal to bone cut

soft_tissue.vessels: Ligate anterior tibial, posterior tibial, peroneal
soft_tissue.closure: Myoplasty - secure flap to anterior compartment/tibia

definition.@value: Major limb amputation through the tibia and fibula below the knee joint, preserving the knee for prosthetic rehabilitation.

sources.reference: SVS/APMA/SVM Clinical Practice Guidelines on Lower Extremity Amputation

learning_objectives: Describe the surgical technique including posterior flap design
Explain why knee preservation is critical for rehabilitation
Apply perfusion criteria for BKA level selection
clinical_pearls: Preserve the knee - AKA requires 40-60% more energy to walk than BKA
Palpable popliteal pulse is the best predictor of BKA healing
Posterior flap should be 2x the length of anterior flap
Bevel the tibia anteriorly to prevent skin breakdown
70-80% of BKA patients achieve prosthetic ambulation
